title: Carotid Artery Stenosis with TIA
diagnosis_topic: Symptomatic carotid stenosis causing transient ischemic attack
setup_script: A 68-year-old woman presents to your clinic after an episode of sudden left-sided weakness and slurred speech lasting about 30 minutes. Her symptoms resolved spontaneously. She has hypertension, hyperlipidemia, and a 40 pack-year smoking history. On examination, she is neurologically intact. How would you proceed with this patient?

dynamic_flow.reply: BP 150/85 mmHg, HR 78 bpm, RR 16/min, Temp 36.7 °C, SpO₂ 98% on room air.
Normal strength and sensation; no cranial nerve deficits; carotid bruit on the right side.
CBC and BMP are normal; LDL 160 mg/dL.
Non-contrast CT shows no acute infarct or hemorrhage.
80% stenosis of the right internal carotid artery.

dynamic_flow.trigger: If resident asks for confirmatory imaging
dynamic_flow.reply: CTA neck confirms high-grade right ICA stenosis, patent intracranial vessels.
Aspirin and high-dose statin are started.
Patient develops recurrent TIA with left arm weakness lasting 2 hours.

dynamic_flow.trigger: If resident refers to vascular surgery promptly
dynamic_flow.reply: Patient is evaluated for carotid endarterectomy vs. carotid stenting.

dynamic_flow.trigger: If resident asks about timing of surgery
dynamic_flow.reply: Surgery recommended within 2 weeks for symptomatic patients.
Risk of stroke, MI, cranial nerve injury, hematoma; emphasize blood pressure control and continuation of aspirin.
Both regional and general anesthesia are acceptable, depends on institutional and patient factors.

dynamic_flow.trigger: If resident proceeds to operative discussion
dynamic_flow.reply: Carotid endarterectomy is performed; intraoperative findings confirm 80% ICA stenosis.

dynamic_flow.trigger: If resident is asked to describe the operative technique
dynamic_flow.reply: Resident should describe incision along anterior border of sternocleidomastoid, exposure of carotid bifurcation, control of common, internal, and external carotid arteries, arteriotomy, plaque removal, patch closure, and hemostasis.

dynamic_flow.trigger: If resident asks about postoperative monitoring
dynamic_flow.reply: Admit to step-down/ICU for neurologic checks and blood pressure control.

dynamic_flow.trigger: If resident inquires about long-term follow-up
dynamic_flow.reply: Surveillance with carotid duplex at 1 month, then annually.

dynamic_flow.trigger: If resident discusses risk factor modification
dynamic_flow.reply: Smoking cessation, hypertension control, diabetes management, and statin therapy.

dynamic_flow.trigger: If resident fails to initiate medical therapy or delays referral
dynamic_flow.reply: Patient suffers a completed stroke with persistent left hemiparesis.

critical_decision_points: Recognition of TIA as a warning sign for stroke
Appropriate use of brain and vascular imaging
Initiation of best medical therapy (antiplatelet, statin)
Timely referral for carotid endarterectomy or stenting
Understanding perioperative risks and anesthesia considerations
Ability to describe operative technique for carotid endarterectomy
Counseling on long-term risk factor modification and surveillance

Your communication was structured and clear when discussing operative planning and perioperative risks..
